content: How can I help you today?

I don’t really know where to start. My wife and I are going through a lot right now, mostly because of the challenges with our son. It feels like everything is falling apart, and I’m not sure how to fix it.

That sounds really overwhelming. You’re facing challenges with your son, and it’s impacting your relationship with your wife. It can be hard to know where to start when things feel like they’re falling apart. What’s been weighing on you the most lately?

I think it’s just everything piling up. My son’s behavior has been so difficult, and we’ve tried everything we can think of, but nothing seems to work. On top of that, it’s causing so much tension between my wife and me—sometimes we can’t even talk without arguing. I don’t know how to help my son, my marriage, or even myself at this point.

You’re feeling the weight of trying to support your son, your marriage, and yourself, all while it seems like your efforts haven’t been bringing the changes you hope for. That sounds exhausting and discouraging, especially when even communication with your wife is strained. How have you managed to cope with everything so far?

I’m not sure I’ve been coping very well, honestly. I just feel stuck. I try to focus on work or other things, but it’s like I can’t escape the stress, and I end up shutting down. My wife says I’ve been distant, but I don’t even know how to talk about all of this.

It’s been hard for you to escape the stress, and shutting down feels like the only way to handle it at times. You might be trying to protect yourself from feeling overwhelmed, but it’s also making it harder to connect with your wife. It sounds like you care deeply about her and your family. What do you think could help you feel less stuck right now?

I'm not sure, to be honest. I feel like there’s so much going on that I wouldn’t even know where to begin. Maybe just figuring out how to get through one thing at a time? It’s hard to even see what that “one thing” should be.

It’s understandable that with everything going on, figuring out where to start feels overwhelming. Focusing on one thing at a time might help make it all seem a bit more manageable. Is there something that feels most urgent or important to deal with right now, whether it’s with your son, your wife, or even your own well-being?

I'm not sure... I feel like helping my son might be the most urgent, but at the same time, I know my relationship with my wife is critical too. And then there's me—I’m struggling to even keep it together. It's hard to pick one thing because they all feel so connected.

It sounds like you’re juggling a lot, and everything feels intertwined—helping your son, repairing your relationship with your wife, and taking care of yourself. It makes sense that it’s hard to pick one to focus on when they all seem so important. What do you think would need to happen to start feeling even a little relief or clarity in one of these areas?

It’s hard to think about where to start, but maybe if I could figure out what’s really going on with my son and feel like I’m actually helping him, that might take some of the pressure off everything else. I think a big part of the stress comes from feeling helpless with him.

It sounds like understanding your son better and feeling like you’re making a difference could help ease the sense of helplessness, which might then reduce some of the strain in other areas. That’s an important insight. Would it make sense to explore what’s been happening with him lately or how he’s been struggling?

Well, he’s been acting out a lot at home and at school—getting into trouble, having outbursts, and just refusing to listen. I know he’s struggling with something, but I don’t know what it is or how to reach him. It’s frustrating because no matter what we try, nothing seems to calm him down or help him feel better.

Your son’s behavior has been tough to navigate, and it’s hard not knowing what’s driving it or how to help him. It sounds like you’re doing your best to support him, even though it’s been frustrating and exhausting. What steps have you tried so far to connect with him or help him manage those struggles?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting clear rules, taking away privileges, rewarding good behavior—everything we can think of. We even talked to his teacher and made some adjustments at school, but nothing seems to work for long. It feels like he’s angry or upset about something, but he won’t open up to us about it.

You’ve been doing everything you can to help your son—setting boundaries, offering support, and even working with his school—and yet it feels like the root of what’s upsetting him remains out of reach. That must be so disheartening when you’re trying so hard to help him feel better. Is there anything you’ve noticed in his behavior or routines that might give you a clue about what he’s feeling?

One thing I’ve noticed is that he seems to get really frustrated if things don’t go his way or if plans change suddenly. He has a hard time calming down once he’s upset, and sometimes it feels like he’s just testing his limits with us. I don’t know if there’s something more going on, but it’s hard to know how to approach it without making things worse.

It sounds like changes or unexpected situations might be especially upsetting for him, and once he’s upset, it can spiral into frustration and testing boundaries. You’re trying to figure out how to approach this without adding to the tension, which shows a lot of care for his needs. What’s worked—even a little—in helping him calm down or feel understood in the past?

Sometimes giving him some space helps, or just sitting quietly with him until he’s ready to talk. Other times, distraction can work—like asking him to help with something. But those moments feel so rare, and I’m not always sure if I’m doing the right thing.

You’ve noticed that giving him space and being there quietly or finding ways to distract him can sometimes help, even if it feels uncertain. Those are thoughtful approaches that show how much you’re trying to understand and support him, even in tough moments. What do you think might help you feel more confident in handling these situations going forward?
